remarks.para: The hysteresis is an offset that provides padding between the point at which the alarm is raised and the point at which the alarm is cleared. For example, in the case of the operation:

member.summary: Downsampling method enumeration.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.DownsamplingMethod.LastReceived
member.summary: Downsamples to the last measurement received.
member.remarks: Use this option if no downsampling is needed or the selected value is not critical. This is the fastest option if the incoming and outgoing frame rates match.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.DownsamplingMethod.Closest
member.summary: Downsamples to the measurement closest to frame time.
member.remarks: This is the typical operation used when performing simple downsampling. This is the fastest option if the incoming frame rate is faster than the outgoing frame rate.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.DownsamplingMethod.Filtered
member.summary: Downsamples by applying a user-defined value filter over all received measurements to anti-alias the results.
member.remarks: This option will produce the best result but has a processing penalty.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.DownsamplingMethod.BestQuality
member.summary: Downsamples to the measurement that has the best quality closest to frame time.
member.remarks: This option chooses the measurement closest to the frame time with the best quality.

member.name: T:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase
member.summary: Measurement concentrator base class.

remarks.para: This class synchronizes (i.e., sorts by timestamp) real-time measurements.

Note that your lag time should be defined as it relates to the rate at which data data is coming into the concentrator. Make sure you allow enough time for transmission of data over the network allowing any needed time for possible network congestion. Lead time should be defined as your confidence in the accuracy of your local clock (e.g., if you set lead time to 2, this means you trust that your local clock is within plus or minus 2 seconds of real-time.)

This concentrator is designed to sort measurements being transmitted in real-time for data being sent at rates of at least 1 sample per second. Slower rates (e.g., once every few seconds) are not supported since sorting data at these speeds would be trivial. There is no defined maximum number of supported samples per second - but keep in mind that CPU utilization will increase as the measurement volume and frame rate increase.

member.name: M:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new .
member.remarks: Concentration will not begin until consumer "Starts" concentrator (i.e., calling method or setting = true).

member.summary: Creates a new from specified parameters.
member.param: Number of frames to publish per second.
Past time deviation tolerance, in seconds - this becomes the amount of time to wait before publishing begins.
Future time deviation tolerance, in seconds - this becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

remarks.para: must be greater then 0.
must be greater than zero, but can be specified in sub-second intervals (e.g., set to .25 for a quarter-second lag time). Note that this defines time sensitivity to past timestamps.
must be greater than zero, but can be specified in sub-second intervals (e.g., set to .5 for a half-second lead time). Note that this defines time sensitivity to future timestamps.
Concentration will not begin until consumer "Starts" concentrator (i.e., calling method or setting = true).

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.

remarks.para: This property is normally only used when you need the concentrator to send data at faster than real-time speeds, e.g., faster than the defined . A use case would be pushing historical data through the concentrator where you want to sort and publish data as quickly as possible.

With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, e.g., a timer interval, overwhich to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval, i.e., use the , while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

From a real-time perspective the defines its general processing interval based on the defined property. The frames per second property, however, is more than a basic processing interval since it is used to define the intervals in one second that will become the time sorting destination "buckets" used by the concentrator irrespective of the data rate of the incoming data. As an example, if the frames per second of the concentrator is set to 30 and the source data rate is 60fps, then data will be downsampled to 30 frames of sorted incoming data but the assigned processing interval will be used to publish the frames at the specified rate.

The implemented functionality of the process interval property will be to respond to values in the following way:
Value Response
< 0
In this case the default processing interval has been requested, as a result the will be set to false and the concentrator processing interval will be defined based on the currently defined property, e.g., if the frames per second is 30 the processing interval will be 33.33ms.
0
In this case the processing interval has been defined to process data as fast as possible, as a result the property will be set to true and property will be set to false. With a processing interval of zero data is expected to flow into the concentrator as quick as it can be provided. The property will still be used to sort data by time into appropriate frames, but the concentrator will use the reception time of the measurements against the defined lag-time to make sure needed data has arrived before publication and frames will be published at the same rate of data arrival.
> 0
In this case a specific processing interval has been defined for processing data, as a result both the and properties will be set to true. With a specifically defined processing interval, data is expected to flow into the concentrator at a similar rate. The property will still be used to sort data by time into appropriate frames, but the concentrator will use the reception time of the measurements against the defined lag-time to make sure needed data has arrived before publication and frames will be published on the specified interval. If multiple frames are ready for publication when the processing interval executes, then all the ready frames will be published sequentially as quickly as possible.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.MaximumPublicationTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum frame publication timeout in milliseconds, set to (-1) to wait indefinitely.

remarks.para: The concentrator automatically defines a precision timer to provide the heatbeat for frame publication, however if the system gets busy the heartbeat signals can be missed. This property defines a maximum wait timeout before reception of the heartbeat signal to make sure frame publications continue to occur in a timely fashion even when a system is under stress.

This property is automatically defined as 2% more than the number of milliseconds per frame when the property is set. Users can override this default value to provide custom behavior for this timeout.

Desired maximum resolution Value to assign
Seconds .
Milliseconds .
Microseconds .
100-Nanoseconds 0
Assigning values less than zero will be set to zero since minimum possible concentrator resolution is one tick (100-nanoseconds). Assigning values values greater than . will be set to . since maximum possible concentrator resolution is one second (i.e., 1 frame per second).

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.PerformTimestampReasonabilityCheck
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if timestamp reasonability checks should be performed on incoming measurements (i.e., measurement timestamps are compared to system clock for reasonability using tolerance).
member.remarks: Setting this value to false will make the concentrator use the latest value received as "real-time" without validation; this is not recommended in production since time reported by source devices may be grossly incorrect. For non-production configurations, setting this value to false will allow concentration of historical data.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.ProcessByReceivedTimestamp
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if concentrator should sort measurements by received time.

remarks.para: Setting this value to true will make concentrator use the timestamp of measurement reception, which is typically the creation time, for sorting and publication. This is useful in scenarios where the concentrator will be receiving very large volumes of data but not necessarily in real-time, such as, reading values from a file where you want data to be sorted and processed as fast as possible.
Setting this value to true will force to be true and to be false.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.TrackPublishedTimestamp
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if system should track timestamp of publication for all frames and measurements.
member.remarks: Setting this value to true will cause the concentrator to mark the timestamp of publication in each and its measurement's . Since this is extra processing time that may not be needed except in cases of calculating statistics for system performance, this must be explicitly enabled.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.IgnoreBadTimestamps
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if bad timestamps (as determined by measurement's timestamp quality) should be ignored when sorting measurements.
member.remarks: Setting this property to true forces system to use timestamps as-is without checking quality. If this property is true, it will supercede operation of .

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.AllowSortsByArrival
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines whether or not to allow incoming measurements with bad timestamps to be sorted by arrival time.

remarks.para: Value defaults to true, so any incoming measurement with a bad timestamp quality will be sorted according to its arrival time. Setting the property to false will cause all measurements with a bad timestamp quality to be discarded. This property will only be considered when is false.
Value will be forced to false if is true.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.UseLocalClockAsRealTime
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines whether or not to use the local clock time as real-time.

remarks.para: Use your local system clock as real-time only if the time is locally GPS-synchronized, or if the measurement values being sorted were not measured relative to a GPS-synchronized clock.
If is true, will always be set to true, even if you try to set it to false.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.ConcentratorBase.RealTime
member.summary: Gets the the most accurate time value that is available. If = true, then this function will return . Otherwise, this function will return the timestamp of the most recent measurement, or if no measurement timestamps are within time deviation tolerances as specified by the value.
member.remarks: Because the measurements being received by remote devices are often measured relative to GPS time, these timestamps are typically more accurate than the local clock. As a result, we can use the latest received timestamp as the best local time measurement we have (ignoring transmission delays); but, even these times can be incorrect so we still have to apply reasonability checks to these times. To do this, we use the local system time and the value to validate the latest measured timestamp. If the newest received measurement timestamp gets too old or creeps too far into the future (both validated + and - against defined lead time property value), we will fall back on local system time. Note that this creates a dependency on a fairly accurate local clock - the smaller the lead time deviation tolerance, the better the needed local clock accuracy. For example, a lead time deviation tolerance of a few seconds might only require keeping the local clock synchronized to an NTP time source; but, a sub-second tolerance would require that the local clock be very close to GPS time.

member.name: M:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.IAdapter.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing contraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multitple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: E:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.IAdapter.ProcessException
member.summary: Event is raised when there is an exception encountered while processing.

remarks.para: Implementations of this interface are expected to capture any exceptions that might be thrown by user code in any processing to prevent third-party code from causing an unhandled exception in the host. Errors are reported via this event so host administrators will be aware of the exception. Any needed connection cycle to data adapter should be restarted when an exception is encountered.
is the exception that was thrown.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.IActionAdapter.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.IActionAdapter.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: M:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing contraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multitple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.returns: True if minimum needed number of measurements were returned in measurement array

remarks.para: Remember this function will *only* return the minimum needed number of measurements, no more. If you want to use all available measurements in your adapter you should just use Frame.Measurements.Values directly.
Note that the measurements array parameter will be created if the reference is null, otherwise if caller creates array it must be sized to MinimumMeasurementsToUse

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.LagTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed past time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be subsecond).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.
This becomes the amount of delay introduced by the concentrator to allow time for data to flow into the system.

member.exception: LagTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.LeadTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed future time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be subsecond).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.
This becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.ActionAdapterCollection.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.ActionAdapterCollection.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: M:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.AdapterBase.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing contraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multitple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.AdapterBase.ConnectionString
member.summary: Gets or sets key/value pair connection information specific to this .

remarks.para:
Example connection string using measurements defined in a table:
inputMeasurementKeys={FILTER ActiveMeasurements WHERE Company='TVA' AND SignalType='FREQ' ORDER BY ID};
outputMeasurements={FILTER ActiveMeasurements WHERE SignalType IN ('IPHA','VPHA') AND Phase='+'}
Basic filtering syntax is as follows:
{FILTER <TableName> WHERE <Expression> [ORDER BY <SortField>]}
Source tables are expected to have at least the following fields:
Name Type Description.
ID NVARCHAR Measurement key formatted as: ArchiveSource:PointID.
PointTag NVARCHAR Point tag of measurement.
Adder FLOAT Adder to apply to value, if any (default to 0.0).
Multiplier FLOAT Multipler to apply to value, if any (default to 1.0).

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LagTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed past time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be subsecond).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.
This becomes the amount of delay introduced by the concentrator to allow time for data to flow into the system.

member.exception: LagTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LeadTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed future time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be subsecond).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.
This becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.summary: This removes a range of measurements from the internal measurement queue.

member.name: M:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.Flush
member.summary: Blocks the current thread, if the is connected, until all items in queue are processed, and then stops processing.

remarks.para: It is possible for items to be added to the queue while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to process items as quickly as possible until the queue is empty. Unless the user stops queueing items to be processed, the flush call may never return (not a happy situtation on shutdown).
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be items that remain unprocessed in the queue.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.OutputIsForArchive
member.summary: Gets the flag that determines if measurements sent to this are destined for archival.
member.remarks: This property allows the to calculate statistics on how many measurements have been archived per minute. Historians would normally set this property to true; other custom exports would set this property to false.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.SupportsTemporalProcessing
member.summary: Gets the flag indicating if this implementation supports temporal processing.
member.remarks: For output adapters that archive data it is assumed that the desired behavior will be to not support temporal processing since the data being processed has already been archived (i.e., no need to attempt to rearchive old data). As a result the default behavior for an output adapter is to not support temporal processing when is true. If you have an output adapter that you want to support temporal data processing independent of the value, then override this property and force the base value to the desired state.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the output adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, overwhich to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.summary: Gets flag that determines if the data output stream connects asynchronously.
member.remarks: Derived classes should return true when data output stream connects asynchronously, otherwise return false.

member.name: M:TimeSeriesFramework.Statistics.StatisticsEngine.RegexMatch(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the given signal reference matches the signal reference regular expression using the given suffix.
member.param: The signal reference to be matched against the regular expression.
The suffix used by a particular type of statistic.
member.returns: Flag indicating whether the signal reference matches the regular expression.
member.remarks: The format for signal reference of statistics is: ACRONYM!SUFFIX-ST#, where ACRONYM is the acronym of the measurement's source, SUFFIX is the suffix given as a parameter to this method, and # is an index used to differentiate between statistics with the same source and type.

member.name: T:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand
member.summary: Server commands received by and sent by .
member.remarks: Solicited server commands will receive a or response code along with an associated success or failure message. Message type for successful responses will be based on server command - for example, server response for a successful MetaDataRefresh command will return a serialized of the available server metadata. Message type for failed responses will always be a string of text respresenting the error message.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.Authenticate
member.summary: Authenticate command.
member.remarks: Requests that server authenticate client with the following encrypted authentication packet. Successful return message type will be string indicating client ID was validated. Client should not attempt further steps if authentication fails, user will need to take action. Client should send MetaDataRefresh and Subscribe commands upon successful authentication. If server is setup to not require authentication, authentication step can be skipped - however it will be up to the implementation to know if authentication is required - the server cannot be queried to determine if authentication is required. It is expected that use of this protocol between gateways over a shared network (i.e., the lower security zone) will require authentication. It is expected that use of this protocol between gateway and other systems (e.g., a PDC) in a private network (i.e., the higher security zone) can be setup to not require authentication.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.MetaDataRefresh
member.summary: Meta data refresh command.
member.remarks: Requests that server send an updated set of metadata so client can refresh its point list. Successful return message type will be a containing server device and measurement metadata. Received device list should be defined as children of the "parent" server device connection similar to the way PMUs are defined as children of a parent PDC device connection. Devices and measurements contain unique Guids that should be used to key metadata updates in local repository.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.Subscribe
member.summary: Subscribe command.
member.remarks: Requests a subscription of streaming data from server based on connection string that follows. It will not be necessary to stop an existing subscription before requesting a new one. Successful return message type will be string indicating total number of allowed points. Client should wait for UpdateSignalIndexCache and UpdateBaseTime response codes before attempting to parse data when using the compact measurement format.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.Unsubscribe
member.summary: Unsubscribe command.
member.remarks: Requests that server stop sending streaming data to the client and cancel the current subscription.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.RotateCipherKeys
member.summary: Rotate cipher keys.
member.remarks: Manually requests that server send a new set of cipher keys for data packet encryption.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.UpdateProcessingInterval
member.summary: Update processing interval.
member.remarks: Manually requests server to update the processing interval with the following specified value.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerCommand.DefineOperationalModes
member.summary: Define operational modes for subscriber connection.
member.remarks: As soon as connection is established, requests that server set operational modes that affect how the subscriber and publisher will communicate.

member.name: T:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse
member.summary: Server responses sent by and received by .

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.Succeeded
member.summary: Command succeeded response.
member.remarks: Informs client that its solicited server command succeeded, original command and success message follow.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.Failed
member.summary: Command failed response.
member.remarks: Informs client that its solicited server command failed, original command and failure message follow.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.DataPacket
member.summary: Data packet response.
member.remarks: Unsolicited response informs client that a data packet follows.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.UpdateSignalIndexCache
member.summary: Update signal index cache response.
member.remarks: Unsolicited response requests that client update its runtime signal index cache with the one that follows.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.UpdateBaseTimes
member.summary: Update runtime base-timestamp offsets response.
member.remarks: Unsolicited response requests that client update its runtime base-timestamp offsets with those that follow.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.UpdateCipherKeys
member.summary: Update runtime cipher keys response.
member.remarks: Response, solicited or unsolicited, requests that client update its runtime data cipher keys with those that follow.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.DataStartTime
member.summary: Data start time response packet.
member.remarks: Unsolicited response provides the start time of data being processed from the first measurement.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.ProcessingComplete
member.summary: Processing complete notification.
member.remarks: Unsolicited response provides notification that input processing has completed, typically via temporal constraint.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.ServerResponse.NoOP
member.summary: No operation keep-alive ping.
member.remarks: The command channel can remain quiet for some time, this command allows a period test of client connectivity.

member.name: T:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.DataPacketFlags
member.summary: data packet flags.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.DataPacketFlags.Synchronized
member.summary: Determines if data packet is synchronized.
member.remarks: Bit set = synchronized, bit clear = unsynchronized.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.DataPacketFlags.Compact
member.summary: Determines if serialized measurement is compact.
member.remarks: Bit set = compact, bit clear = full fidelity.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.DataPacketFlags.CipherIndex
member.summary: Detemines which cipher index to use when encrypting data packet.
member.remarks: Bit set = use odd cipher index (i.e., 1), bit clear = use even cipher index (i.e., 0).

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.DataPacketFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags set.
member.remarks: This would represent unsynchronized, full fidelity measurement data packets.

member.name: T:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes
member.summary: Operational modes that affect how and communicate.
member.remarks: Operational modes only apply to fundamental protocol control.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.VersionMask
member.summary: Mask to get version number of protocol.
member.remarks: Version number is currently set to 0.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressionModeMask
member.summary: Mask to get mode of compression.
member.remarks: Compression mode is currently not supported. These bits are simply reserved for different compression modes.

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.EncodingMask
member.summary: Mask to get character encoding used when exchanging messages between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks:
00 = UTF-16 little endian
01 = UTF-16 big endian
10 = UTF-8
11 = ANSI

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.UseCommonSerializationFormat
member.summary: Determines type of serialization to use when exchanging signal index cache and metadata.
member.remarks: Bit set = common serialization format, bit clear = .NET serialization format

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressSignalIndexCache
member.summary: Determines whether the signal index cache is compressed when exchanging between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks: Bit set = compress, bit clear = no compression

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressMetadata
member.summary: Determines whether is compressed when exchanging between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks: Bit set = compress, bit clear = no compression

member.name: F:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.OperationalModes.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags set.
member.remarks: This would represent protocol version 0, UTF-16 little endian character encoding, .NET serialization and no compression.

The desired number of data frames per second.

Desired UDP return data channel connection string to use for data packet transmission. Set to null to use TCP channel for data transmission.
Boolean value that determines whether or not to use the local clock time as real-time.
Boolean value that determines if bad timestamps (as determined by measurement's timestamp quality) should be ignored when sorting measurements.
Gets or sets flag that determines whether or not to allow incoming measurements with bad timestamps to be sorted by arrival time.
Gets or sets the maximum time resolution, in ticks, to use when sorting measurements by timestamps into their proper destination frame.
Gets or sets flag that allows system to preemptively publish frames assuming all expected measurements have arrived.
Gets the total number of downsampled measurements processed by the concentrator.
Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint to use for historical playback.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint to use for historical playback.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint to use for historical playback.
Defines the desired processing interval milliseconds, i.e., historical play back speed, to use when temporal constraints are defined.
Comma separated list of wait handle names used to establish external event wait handles needed for inter-adapter synchronization.
Maximum wait time for external events, in milliseconds, before proceeding.
member.returns: true if subscribe transmission was successful; otherwise false.

remarks.para: When the or temporal processing contraints are defined (i.e., not null), this specifies the start and stop time over which the subscriber session will process data. Passing in null for the and specifies the the subscriber session will process data in standard, i.e., real-time, operation.

With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, the value specifies the desired historical playback data processing interval in milliseconds. This is basically a delay, or timer interval, overwhich to process data. Setting this value to -1 means to use the default processing interval while setting the value to 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

remarks.para: This value defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
Defined the number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.TemporalMeasurement.LeadTime
member.summary: Allowed future time deviation tolerance in seconds (can be subsecond).

remarks.para: This value defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
Defined the number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: T:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SignalIndexCache
member.summary: Represents a serializable signal ID to index cross reference.
member.remarks: This class is used to create a runtime index to be used for data exchange so that a 16-bit integer is exchanged in the data packets for signal identification instead of the 128-bit Guid signal ID to reduce bandwidth required for signal exchange. This means the total number of unique signal IDs that could be exchanged using this method in a single session is 65,535. This number seems reasonable for the currently envisioned use cases, however, multiple sessions each with their own runtime signal index cache could be established if this is a limitation for a given data set.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SubscriptionInfo.StartTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the start time of the requested temporal session for streaming historic data.

remarks.para: When the or temporal processing contraints are defined (i.e., not null), this specifies the start and stop time over which the subscriber session will process data. Passing in null for the and specifies the the subscriber session will process data in standard, i.e., real-time, operation.

Both the and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SubscriptionInfo.StopTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the stop time of the requested temporal session for streaming historic data.

remarks.para: When the or temporal processing contraints are defined (i.e., not null), this specifies the start and stop time over which the subscriber session will process data. Passing in null for the and specifies the the subscriber session will process data in standard, i.e., real-time, operation.

Both the and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SubscriptionInfo.ConstraintParameters
member.summary: Gets or sets the aditional constraint parameters supplied to temporal adapters in a temporal session.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SubscriptionInfo.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the processing interval requested by the subscriber. A value of -1 indicates the default processing interval. A value of 0 indicates data will be processed as fast as possible.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, the value specifies the desired historical playback data processing interval in milliseconds. This is basically a delay, or timer interval, overwhich to process data. Setting this value to -1 means to use the default processing interval while setting the value to 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SubscriptionInfo.WaitHandleNames

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SubscriptionInfo.WaitHandleTimeout

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.TimeResolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum time resolution, in ticks, to use when sorting measurements by timestamps into their proper destination frame.
member.remarks:
Desired maximum resolution Value to assign
Seconds .
Milliseconds .
Microseconds .
100-Nanoseconds 0
Assigning values less than zero will be set to zero since minimum possible concentrator resolution is one tick (100-nanoseconds). Assigning values values greater than . will be set to . since maximum possible concentrator resolution is one second (i.e., 1 frame per second).

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SynchronizedClientSubscription.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, overwhich to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SynchronizedClientSubscription.InputMeasurementKeys
member.summary: Gets or sets primary keys of input measurements the expects, if any.
member.remarks: We override method so assignment can be synchronized such that dynamic updates won't interfere with filtering in .

member.name: P:TimeSeriesFramework.Transport.SynchronizedClientSubscription.SupportsTemporalProcessing
member.summary: Gets the flag indicating if this adapter supports temporal processing.
member.remarks: Although this adapter provisions support for temporal processing by proxying historical data to a remote sink, the adapter does not need to be automatically engaged within an actual temporal , therefore this method returns false to make sure the adapter doesn't get automatically instantiated within a temporal session.
